item.title: Turn Linux into a Software Switch with NetworkManager
item.description:
Some context

A few weeks ago, I started building a lab in GNS3 to brush up on my intrusion detection skills. I installed Wazuh in my lab and its agent software on my endpoints and everything worked well. However, I quickly realized that I was missing an important part in my detection: network data. I decided I would use Suricata to gather this data, but ran into a small problem: virtual switches in GNS3 are helpful for forwarding L2 packets, but they lack advanced features such as port mirroring (which would allow me to send copies of packets to Suricata for monitoring). Without this function, I had to find an alternative solution so Suricata could sniff all the traffic on my network.

item.description:
Note: you must follow these configuration steps on both ends of the tunnel.

What is IPsec?

IPsec is a suite of protocols used to create secure tunnels across insecure networks (like the internet). Two routers (also called peers) are used to establish the tunnel.

IPsec also provides authentication, ensuring that only authenticated peers can connect.

Finally, any traffic carried by IPsec is encrypted to maintain confidentiality.

What Traffic Does IPsec Transport?

IPsec can be configured to transport specific types of traffic based on defined rules. Traffic that matches these rules is referred to as interesting traffic. If the traffic matches one of the rules, IPsec will use the tunnel to deliver it.

item.title: NAT Configuration on Cisco IOS
item.description:
Dynamic NAT Overload (PAT)

What is it?

NAT Overload, also known as PAT (Port Address Translation) is a type of NAT configuration that allows multiple devices in a network to share a single public IP address. What makes this type of NAT “dynamic” is the fact that there is no pre-defined one-to-one mapping between a private IP address and a public IP address (that is, the router takes care of the translation based on our instructions).
